Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\), where \\( \omega \\) is a real constant, representing a periodic signal in the complex plane. We explore the consequences of applying the Fourier transform \\( F \), which converts it into its frequency domain representation.

If during the interval of transformation, a modulation by \\( e^{i\beta t} \\) (where \\( \beta \\) is another constant) is introduced, will the dominant frequency component of the Fourier transform still be at \\( \omega \\)?
Explanation: The introduction of \\( e^{i\beta t} \\) acts as an additional periodic modulation, shifting the original frequency \\( \omega \\) by \\( \beta \\) due to the properties of frequency modulation in Fourier analysis, resulting in a dominant component at \\( \omega + \beta \\).
